attributes.title: A Qualitative Study of People's Moral Considerations towards Social Robots

summary.value: This registration contains a qualitative interview study focusing on the question whether, when and why people may hold moral considerations towards social robots. A detailed description of the project, the research design specifics and plan of analysis are included as a separate document. The topic guide for the semi-structured interviews is included as a document as well.

name.value: Iteration and voting -- Majority & Minority groups

other.value:
These are additional measures we are collecting for exploration and do not have strong hypotheses on: 
What decision rule should the group should use if they are to decide again? (Options: decision rule pre-specified in condition (here, voting), letting the kids that want popcorn get their way, letting the kids that want chips get their way, and deciding another way with an open response).

sample.value: We plan to collect 50 participants per condition. We will aim to recruit 100 total participants.

analyses.value:
T1/T2/T3 fairness evaluations: At each time point, we will compute participants’ mean fairness evaluation and compare participants’ response across the two conditions. We will construct a generalized linear model with fairness evaluation as the outcome variable and condition as the predictor variable. We will test between the alternate hypotheses as described above. One possibility is that the presence of a majority that is grouped will lead participants to view this case as less fair even before any votes take place. In this case, we would expect voting to be viewed as less fair in the Majority Group condition than in the Minority Group condition at T1. 

Difference from T1 to T2: As described above, we will compute the difference between participants’ fairness evaluations at T1 and T2 (T2-T1). We will compare the difference score across the two conditions, again using a generalized linear model with difference score as the outcome and condition as the predictor. 

Difference from T2 to T3: We will compute the difference between participants’ fairness evaluations at T2 and T3 (T3-T2). We will compare this difference score across the two conditions in the same way as described above. We will test between the alternate hypotheses as described above. 

How likely is the decision rule to yield the same outcome: We will compare how likely participants think the decision rule is to yield the same outcome (popcorn) across the two conditions by constructing a generalized linear model with perceived voting outcome as the outcome variable and condition as the predictor. 

Perceived outcome ~ Perceived change in fairness: To examine whether participants’ fairness evaluations relate to how likely they think the procedure is to yield a fixed outcome, we will construct a generalized linear model predicting T3-T2 difference score by perceived outcome and condition (we will examine whether the interaction term explains additional variance). 

Group desire: We will compute a difference score between participants’ judgments of the majority group’s desire and the minority group’s desire (majority desire – minority desire). We will compare this difference score across the two conditions (using a generalized linear model with difference score as the outcome and condition as the predictor). One possibility is that the presence of a social group highlights the group’s shared preference. If this is the case, then one possibility is that participants will respond that a member of the majority wants to vote more in the Majority Group condition and respond that a member of the minority group wants to vote less in the Minority Group condition. 

Difference in group desire ~ Perceived change in fairness: To examine whether participants’ judgments of the group members’ desires relates to their perception of fairness, we will construct a generalized linear model predicting difference in group preference (majority-minority) by change in perceived fairness (T3-T2). We will also examine the relation between each groups’ preference (majority desire; minority desire) and change in perceived fairness (T3-T2). One possibility is that people’s perceptions depend more on the majority group’s desire in the Majority Group condition and more on the minority group’s desire in the Minority Group condition. 

Difference in group desire ~ Perceived outcome: Finally, we will examine whether participants’ judgments of the groups’ desires relates to how likely they think the voting procedure is to yield popcorn as the outcome. To do so, we will again construct a generalized linear model with difference in group desire (majority-minority) as the outcome variable and perceived voting outcome (% yielding popcorn) and condition as predictor variables (we will consider whether the interaction term explains additional variance).

dependent.value:
The key DVs are fairness evaluations at three different time points: T1 (before a decision is made), T2 (after the first decision is made), and T3 (after three decisions are made). Fairness evaluations will be measured on a 1-7 Likert scale (extremely unfair to extremely fair). We will also ask participants how likely they believe the decision rule is to yield the same outcome if used again (scale from 1 to 100). 

We will calculate difference scores between T1 & T2 and between T2 & T3. 

We will ask participants to evaluate how likely it will be that a member of the majority of kids will want to use the decision rule again and how likely it will be that a member of the minority of kids will want to use the decision rule again. We will calculate a difference score between these two judgments.

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to 1 of 2 conditions: the Group Majority condition or Group Minority condition.

hypothesis.value:
This study examines how adults think about the functionality of voting as a decision-rule. We ask how participants think about the fairness of iterated votes between two social groups. Specifically, we test whether people’s perceptions of voting depend more on a majority group winning or on a minority group losing. 

In our previous studies, participants saw several stories about five characters making a decision together about whether to eat popcorn or chips for snack time. Participants were told that these characters would make a decision by voting. We asked participants how fair it was to vote across three repeated trials. We found that voting was evaluated as increasingly less fair across iteration, but only when preferences were stable and unchanging (and especially if preferences were linked to group membership)—that is, when a majority group consistently got their way over a minority group. Interestingly, this was also true before participants viewed the outcome of any votes: participants evaluated voting as less fair in situations where characters belonged to clear social groups than in situations where characters were not grouped. This finding suggests that adults may infer fixed preferences from the presence of social group membership and use this inference to predict that voting will lead to an unfair outcome. These results highlight how the presence of groups informs adults’ evaluations of voting. However these past studies confound a majority group repeatedly winning with a minority group repeatedly losing. It is unclear whether participants’ evaluations result more from a majority group winning, from a minority group losing, or from both. 

In this next study, we will examine the salience of winners and losers in participants’ evaluations of voting as a process. We will show participants one of two conditions: a Group Minority condition and a Group Majority condition. Across the conditions, all characters will be identified with a different color, but some characters will be the only character of their color (e.g., one Pink, one Orange, etc.) and others will be grouped by color (e.g., two Blues). In each condition, participants will see a classroom with five children who are making a collective decision about what to eat for snack time. In each case, a majority of children will always vote for popcorn. Thus, the same three children will win three times in a row. In the Group Majority condition, these winning children will all be part of the same social group (e.g., all Blue), and the losing children will not be grouped (e.g., one Pink, one Orange). In the Group Minority condition, the losing children will be grouped (e.g., all Blue), and the winning children will not be grouped (e.g., one Pink, one Orange, one Green). In other words, we will vary between conditions whether the majority or minority are groups or sets of individuals. This design will allow us to test whether participants are particularly sensitive towards the same group winning or losing across iterations, or whether both outcomes are equally disliked. 

Here, we have three competing hypotheses: 

H1: People’s tendency to view voting as less fair over iterated trials is driven by people disliking a majority group repeatedly getting its way. Thus, voting will be viewed as less fair in the Majority Group condition compared to in the Minority Group condition. We could see this at two different time points: one possibility is that the presence of a majority group makes voting seem less fair at Timepoint 1 (before any decision is made using the procedure) than when participants see a minority group present. Another possibility (that is not mutually exclusive), is that the difference between the two cases is only apparent after some iterations (at Timepoint 3). If the mere presence of a majority group makes participants more sensitive to the fact that voting is likely to yield the same outcome across iterations of voting (because participants expect the majority itself may vote by group lines), then we would expect to see a difference at T1 across conditions. If instead we expect that both the majority and minority are required to be in groups to make an inference about preferences by group lines, then this difference may only appear after iterated trials. Thus we would not expect to see a difference at T1 across conditions, but would expect to see this difference at T3.

H2: People’s tendency to view voting as less fair over iterated trials is driven by people disliking a minority group repeatedly NOT getting their way. It could be that participants are particularly focused on the oppression of the losing group in regard to voting, and dislike when some characters never get their way as a result of a winner-takes-all voting system. If this is the case, then we would expect participants to evaluate voting as less fair in the Minority Group condition compared to the Majority Group condition. As above, if this difference results from the mere presence of a minority group, we would expect to see this difference at T1. In contrast, if this difference depends on seeing that these preferences are fixed, this difference may only emerge at T3. 

H3: Finally, a third possibility is that people are equally sensitive to a majority group repeatedly winning and to a minority group repeatedly losing. In this case, we would expect voting to be evaluated as increasingly less fair across iterations in both conditions.

attributes.title: Risk Factors for Rapid Chondrolysis After Partial Lateral Meniscectomy: A Scoping Review of the Literature

q1.value: Risk Factors for Rapid Chondrolysis After Partial Lateral Meniscectomy: A Scoping Review of the Literature

q3.value:
Rapid chondrolysis following partial lateral meniscectomy is rare. The risk factors and pathophysiology of this complication have not been established.
The purpose of this study is to perform a scoping review of the literature in order to determine potential risk factors and pathogenesis.

q4.value: Hypothesis: The pathogenesis remains unclear but may be explained by a biological cascade triggered by mechanical focal cartilage overloading.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
A scoping review of the literature was conducted in accordance with the five-stage methodological framework of Arksey and O’Malley and the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses extension for Scoping Reviews (PRISMA-ScR).
The research question was “What is known from the existing literature regarding the pathophysiology and risk factors for rapid chondrolysis after partial lateral meniscectomy?”
Relevant studies were identified by applying the search strategy to the PubMed database. This comprised of the following keywords [“chondrolysis” AND “knee”], [“chondrolysis” AND “meniscus”] and [“chondral damage” AND “lateral meniscus”] with automatic mapping to MeSH terms. The search was conducted on the 28th of June 2019 by two independent investigators (XX and YY blinded for review). Both investigators reviewed the titles and abstracts of all identified records and potentially eligible articles were retrieved for full text review.
All identified clinical studies and case series reporting rapid chondrolysis after PLM were included. Articles were only excluded if a history of inflammatory arthritis or intra-articular local anaesthetic administration were reported because both are recognised to be independently associated with chondrolysis. Any disagreement between reviewers regarding study eligibility were resolved through discussion. 
Due to a small number of published studies and heterogeneity between them, no statistical analyses were performed. Instead the findings were summarised through a narrative analysis of the included published literature. The risk of bias was assessed based on the approach reported by Murad et al. The level of evidence of each article was classified according to the adjusted Oxford Centre For Evidence-Based Medicine 2011 criteria.1 The overall quality of evidence for each of the potential risk factors studied was assessed using the GRADE (Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluation) working group criteria.2,3

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

q11.value: A search strategy based on the terms [“Chondrolysis” AND “Knee”],  [“Chondrolysis” AND “Meniscus”] and [“Chondral damage” AND “ Lateral meniscus”]  was applied to the PubMed database on 28th June 2019. All relevant studies were included. Patient demographics and clinical data were extracted from these studies and analyzed in order to provide an overview of the characteristics of patients who were diagnosed with rapid chondrolysis

Relevant studies were identified by applying the search strategy to the PubMed database. This comprised of the following keywords [“chondrolysis” AND “knee”], [“chondrolysis” AND “meniscus”] and [“chondral damage” AND “lateral meniscus”] with automatic mapping to MeSH terms. Risk Factors of rapid chondrolysis after partial lateral meniscectomy :
Sex
Age (years)
Type of Sports
Level of Play
Limb Alignment (HKA°)

Clinical data:
Type of LM Tear
Chondrolysis Grade
Return to Sport (RTS)

Due to a small number of published studies and heterogeneity between them, no statistical analyses were performed. Instead the findings were summarised through a narrative analysis of the included published literature. The risk of bias was assessed based on the approach reported by Murad et al. The level of evidence of each article was classified according to the adjusted Oxford Centre For Evidence-Based Medicine 2011 criteria.1 The overall quality of evidence for each of the potential risk factors studied was assessed using the GRADE (Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluation) working group criteria.

1. Alford JW, Lewis P, Kang RW, Cole BJ. Rapid progression of chondral disease in the lateral compartment of the knee following meniscectomy. Arthroscopy. 2005;21(12):1505-1509. doi:10.1016/j.arthro.2005.03.036
2. Ishida K, Kuroda R, Sakai H, Doita M, Kurosaka M, Yoshiya S. Rapid chondrolysis after arthroscopic partial lateral meniscectomy in athletes: a case report. Knee Surg Sports Traumatol Arthrosc. 2006;14(12):1266-1269. doi:10.1007/s00167-006-0091-0
3. Mariani PP, Garofalo R, Margheritini F. Chondrolysis after partial lateral meniscectomy in athletes. Knee Surg Sports Traumatol Arthrosc. 2008;16(6):574-580. doi:10.1007/s00167-008-0508-z

registration_responses.q1: Risk Factors for Rapid Chondrolysis After Partial Lateral Meniscectomy: A Scoping Review of the Literature
registration_responses.q3:
Rapid chondrolysis following partial lateral meniscectomy is rare. The risk factors and pathophysiology of this complication have not been established.
The purpose of this study is to perform a scoping review of the literature in order to determine potential risk factors and pathogenesis.
registration_responses.q4: Hypothesis: The pathogenesis remains unclear but may be explained by a biological cascade triggered by mechanical focal cartilage overloading.
registration_responses.q5: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration following analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11: A search strategy based on the terms [“Chondrolysis” AND “Knee”],  [“Chondrolysis” AND “Meniscus”] and [“Chondral damage” AND “ Lateral meniscus”]  was applied to the PubMed database on 28th June 2019. All relevant studies were included. Patient demographics and clinical data were extracted from these studies and analyzed in order to provide an overview of the characteristics of patients who were diagnosed with rapid chondrolysis

registration_responses.q8.question:
A scoping review of the literature was conducted in accordance with the five-stage methodological framework of Arksey and O’Malley and the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses extension for Scoping Reviews (PRISMA-ScR).
The research question was “What is known from the existing literature regarding the pathophysiology and risk factors for rapid chondrolysis after partial lateral meniscectomy?”
Relevant studies were identified by applying the search strategy to the PubMed database. This comprised of the following keywords [“chondrolysis” AND “knee”], [“chondrolysis” AND “meniscus”] and [“chondral damage” AND “lateral meniscus”] with automatic mapping to MeSH terms. The search was conducted on the 28th of June 2019 by two independent investigators (XX and YY blinded for review). Both investigators reviewed the titles and abstracts of all identified records and potentially eligible articles were retrieved for full text review.
All identified clinical studies and case series reporting rapid chondrolysis after PLM were included. Articles were only excluded if a history of inflammatory arthritis or intra-articular local anaesthetic administration were reported because both are recognised to be independently associated with chondrolysis. Any disagreement between reviewers regarding study eligibility were resolved through discussion. 
Due to a small number of published studies and heterogeneity between them, no statistical analyses were performed. Instead the findings were summarised through a narrative analysis of the included published literature. The risk of bias was assessed based on the approach reported by Murad et al. The level of evidence of each article was classified according to the adjusted Oxford Centre For Evidence-Based Medicine 2011 criteria.1 The overall quality of evidence for each of the potential risk factors studied was assessed using the GRADE (Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development and Evaluation) working group criteria.2,3

attributes.title: Dissociating cue and context fear conditioning

q1.value: Dissociating cue and context fear conditioning

q3.value:
In accordance with Nadel and Willner's postulated dual-process theory (1980) a lot of studies have examined cue fear conditioning and context fear conditioning separately. We will conduct this study combining cue and context conditioning to close the existing gap in the literature.

Therefor we will use two office rooms. One of those offices will function as the fear-associated context, the other one as the safety-associated context. One of the objects in the fear-associated context will be used as the threat cue, followed by an electric shock when being focused, another object will function as the safety cue (no shock). In the safety-associated context two objects will be used as the safety control cues (no shocks), respectively. In the test phase, the original fear-associated and safety-associated contexts will be presented as well as the fear-associated context containing the safety control cues or new stimuli instead of the original threat cue and safety cue and the safety-associated context containing the threat cue and safety cue or new stimuli instead of the original safety control cues.

Whereas most fear conditioning studies only concentrated on physiological fear reactions like skin conductance or heart rate changes, we will additionally investigate visual exploration patterns using eye-tracking (latency of first fixation and fixation duration).

q4.value:
Fear reactions will be quantified on the level of subjective ratings (contingency and threat), physiological responses (heart rate deceleration and amplitude of skin conductance responses) and oculomotor behavior (latency of first fixation and fixation duration).

Hypothesis 1: Concerning fear reactions to individual cues (i.e., objects) in oculomotor behavior (lower latency of first fixation and longer fixation duration) and subjective ratings (contingency and threat) we expect:

a) Stronger fear reactions for the threat cue as compared to the safety cue, the safety control cues and new stimuli (elemental view).

b) Stronger fear reactions to the safety cue as compared to the safety control cues and new stimuli (conjunctive view).

Hypothesis 2: Concerning the physiological expression of fear reactions (heart rate deceleration and skin conductance increase) and subjective ratings (contingency and threat) measured within a whole context we expect:

a) Stronger fear reactions to the fear-associated than the safety-associated context (conjunctive view). 

b) Stronger fear reactions to the safety-associated context containing the threat cue and safety cue than to the same context including the safety control cues or new stimuli (elemental view). 

c) Stronger fear reactions to the safety control cues and new stimuli in the fear-associated context as compared to the same cues in the safety-associated context (conjunctive view).

d) Stronger fear reactions to the threat cue and safety cue in the safety-associated context as  compared to safety control cues or new stimuli shown in the fear-associated context (elemental view).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: 2x4-within subjects design with factors "Context" (safety- vs. fear-associated context) and "Cue" (threat cue vs. safety cue vs. safety control cues vs. new object stimuli). Participants will complete a habituation, an acquisition and a test phase in sequential order.

q9.value: For each participant and each phase the trials will be presented in random order.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited via the platform "sona systems", social media platforms and flyers posted on bulletin boards at the University of Würzburg. Participants will receive course credits or will be financially compensated. 

Participants must be at least 18 years old and younger than 41 years, must not suffer from any forms of uncorrected poor eyesight (for example color-blindness, myopia, hyperopia), psychiatric or neurological disorders or take psychotropic substances or drugs and must not wear eye makeup. Participants with poor eyesight can participate when wearing soft contact lenses.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 48 participants. Datasets with missing or invalid data (e.g., due to technical difficulties), participants receiving less than 50% shocks in the acquisition phase (due to not fixating the threat cue) will be replaced until reaching the final sample size.

question.value: We will manipulate in which room the stimuli are presented (fear-associated or safety-associated context) and the cues that are shown in the respective room (1 threat cue + 1 safety cue/2 safety control cues/2 new stimuli).

Outcome measure 1 will be threat ratings concerning the 2 rooms and the 6 different object stimuli (i.e., cues). We will measure this after habituation (only ratings of the 2 rooms), acquisition and the test phase by asking the participants 'How threatening does this room/object appear to you?' (on a scale of 0 - 100 %, 0 being 'not at all', 100 being 'extremely').

Outcome measure 2 will be contingency ratings (contingency between the presentation of a certain room/a certain stimulus and shock application) concerning the 2 rooms and the 6 different object stimuli. Similar to the threat ratings, we will measure this after habituation (only ratings of the 2 rooms), acquisition and the test phase by asking the participants 'How high was the probability of obtaining an electric shock when having been confronted with this room/object?' (on a scale of 0 - 100 %, 0 being 'never', 100 being 'always').

Outcome measure 3 will be the latency of the first fixation on the object/cue after stimulus onset in ms.

Outcome measure 4 will be the cumulative fixation duration on objects/cues. This measure will be normalized with respect to the overall duration of fixations during scene viewing to yield proportions.

Outcome measure 5 will be the heart rate deceleration during scene presentation. Heart rate will be quantified using a second-by-second sampling for the whole stimulus duration and overall responses will be calculated by averaging heart rate values across time bins. 

Outcome measure 6 will be the maximal skin conductance increase during 1-10 s after stimulus onset.

We will use the mean of the reactions towards the two safety control cues as well as the mean of the reactions towards the two new stimuli in order to compare them to the reactions towards the threat cue and safety cue.

Measured variables indicating responses to individual cues (see Hypothesis 1) or contexts (see Hypothesis 2) in the test phase will be analyzed using a 2x4 repeated measures ANOVA with "Context" (safety- vs. fear-associated context) and "Cue" (threat cue vs. safety cue vs. safety control cues vs. new object stimuli) as within-subject factors. Following statistically significant main or interaction effects, individual planned contrasts will be calculated to address pairwise comparisons between conditions (see Hypotheses).

In order to assess the effectiveness of the conditioning procedure, we will also compare subjective context ratings and physiological responses between the habituation and the acquisition phase by means of pairwise t-tests.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the t-test or ANOVA and the contrast analyses suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypotheses were correct.

attributes.title: Altering bindings of action effect features by affective enrichment

q1.value: Altering bindings of action effect features by affective enrichment

q2.value: Viola Mocke, Wilfried Kunde, Klaus Rothermund

q3.value:
Previous work has already reported preliminary evidence for integration of affective features in event-files (Eder, Müsseler, & Hommel, 2012). Closely linked is the question whether assigning a certain valence to an action effect results in increased relevance and therefore altered binding effects. One first indicator for such an influence of action effect valence on binding is a study showing that rewarding actions can strengthen action-effect bindings (Eder, Erle, & Kunde, 2019). Here, participants learned in an acquisition phase that certain actions (i.e., button presses) result in auditory effects while some but not all actions are financially rewarded. In a test phase, they found prime compatibility effects in RTs to be larger for previously rewarded keypresses in comparison to previously unrewarded or punished keypresses
The present research attempts to shed further light on this by altering typically observed binding effects, that is, partial overlap costs when body-related and body-external action effect features partly overlap vs. fully repeat/alternate. Such binding effects manifest in 2 x 2 interactions between body-related and body-external effect feature overlap in RTs and error rates for action B in an ABBA paradigm (Stoet & Hommel, 1999). Depending on the affective value (positive, negative or neutral), that is, the result of assigning valence to the superficially identical body-external action effects, this interaction should turn out more or less pronounced.

q4.value:
Individual analysis of valence conditions:
Functional equivalence benefit: lower RTs and error rates when distal action effect (towards vs. away movement) repeats vs. alternates.
Binding effect (Partial overlap cost): lower RTs and error rates when both body-related and body-external effect features alternate / repeat vs. partial feature repetition 
Comparison of valence conditions:
The binding effect (partial overlap – full alternation/repetition) differs between the valence conditions
The functional equivalence benefit (body-external effect repeats vs. changes) differs between the valence conditions
Possible Outcomes (in orthogonal contrast codes, linear and quadratic):

As in Eder et al. (2019): positive valence strengthens binding compared to no / negative valence
	Neutral Negative Positive 
A1	-.5	0	.5
A2	.5	-1	.5
Assigning meaning to the effect strengthens binding irrespective of valence

	Neutral Negative Positive 
B1	0	-.5	.5
B2	-1	.5	.5

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

2 X 2 X 3 within-subject design

DV: Reaction times and error rates

registration_responses.q3:
Previous work has already reported preliminary evidence for integration of affective features in event-files (Eder, Müsseler, & Hommel, 2012). Closely linked is the question whether assigning a certain valence to an action effect results in increased relevance and therefore altered binding effects. One first indicator for such an influence of action effect valence on binding is a study showing that rewarding actions can strengthen action-effect bindings (Eder, Erle, & Kunde, 2019). Here, participants learned in an acquisition phase that certain actions (i.e., button presses) result in auditory effects while some but not all actions are financially rewarded. In a test phase, they found prime compatibility effects in RTs to be larger for previously rewarded keypresses in comparison to previously unrewarded or punished keypresses
The present research attempts to shed further light on this by altering typically observed binding effects, that is, partial overlap costs when body-related and body-external action effect features partly overlap vs. fully repeat/alternate. Such binding effects manifest in 2 x 2 interactions between body-related and body-external effect feature overlap in RTs and error rates for action B in an ABBA paradigm (Stoet & Hommel, 1999). Depending on the affective value (positive, negative or neutral), that is, the result of assigning valence to the superficially identical body-external action effects, this interaction should turn out more or less pronounced.
registration_responses.q4:
Individual analysis of valence conditions:
Functional equivalence benefit: lower RTs and error rates when distal action effect (towards vs. away movement) repeats vs. alternates.
Binding effect (Partial overlap cost): lower RTs and error rates when both body-related and body-external effect features alternate / repeat vs. partial feature repetition 
Comparison of valence conditions:
The binding effect (partial overlap – full alternation/repetition) differs between the valence conditions
The functional equivalence benefit (body-external effect repeats vs. changes) differs between the valence conditions
Possible Outcomes (in orthogonal contrast codes, linear and quadratic):

As in Eder et al. (2019): positive valence strengthens binding compared to no / negative valence
	Neutral Negative Positive 
A1	-.5	0	.5
A2	.5	-1	.5
Assigning meaning to the effect strengthens binding irrespective of valence

	Neutral Negative Positive 
B1	0	-.5	.5
B2	-1	.5	.5

attributes.title: The effect of focus on sharing a photo in communicating experiences

q1.value: The effect of focus on sharing a photo in communicating experiences

q3.value: In online reviews, consumers write about their experience and sometimes they add a picture to their reviews. In big datasets from Yelp and TripAdvisor, we find that consumers use greater number of words that show their visual focus particularly when they share a picture together with their review. In this study, we test whether people’s focus impacts how they communicate their experiences in general. Specifically, we test whether consumers are more likely to share a picture when they focus on visual (vs. non-visual) aspects of their experience while communicating this experience with other people.

q4.value: We predict a main effect of focus on likelihood of sharing a picture when people communicate their experiences to others. Specifically, we expect that participants in the visual focus condition are more likely to share a picture when they communicate this experience to others than people in the non-visual focus condition.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Two-groups between-subjects design. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the two conditions: visual focus or non-visual focus. In the visual focus condition, participants will be asked to write about their experience by focusing on the look of the food and the design elements in the restaurant that positively influenced your experience. These elements can include how your food or drinks looked when they were served, how the restaurant was decorated, the restaurant's layout, or the lighting and the colors inside the restaurant that might have contributed positively to your experience. In the non-visual focus condition, they will be asked to write about their experience by focusing on the human and service elements in the restaurant that positively influenced their experience. These elements can be how the service employees behaved, how enthusiastic they were attending your requests, and what their tone of voice was like when they served you that might have contributed positively to your experience.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the two conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through the online research platform TurkPrime (newly known as Cloud Research). Participants will be paid $0.7 for agreeing to participate in our 5 minute long study. Participants must be at least 18 years old, and residing in the United States. We will add one screening question to be able to recruit participants relevant to our research questions. Participants must have had dinner at a sit-down restaurant at least once in the last year. This is to ensure that they can write a meaningful review about an actual experience they have had in the past.

q13.value: We will post a study for 400 as the target sample size. We will reject respondents for the following reasons: 1) the restaurant name they identify as writing a review about is not an actual restaurant but rather something else (e.g., a hotel or a retail store), and 2) the review text is irrelevant (e.g., just copying a piece of Wikipedia, etc.).

q14.value: We conducted a power analysis using G*power. To detect a small effect (0.20) at 90% power, the analysis yielded to N = 200 per condition.

q15.value: We do not have a stopping rule. We will run the study until we reach the sample size reported above.

question.value: We will manipulate whether participants focus on the visual or non-visual aspects of the experience they communicate to their friend.

The key dependent variable is was a binary measure of willingness to share a photo with the review (1 = yes, 0 = no). Next, we will ask the type of photo (1= food, 2 = drinks, 3 = menu, 4 = inside the restaurant, 5 = outside the restaurant. 6 = employees, 7 = other) that they have thought of sending with their email. As a manipulation check, they will be asked how much they focused on the human and service elements when they wrote the email (1 = not at all, 7 = a lot). Similarly, they will report how much they focused on the look of the food and design elements when they wrote the email (1 = not at all, 7 = a lot). In order to avoid any bias, these two questions will be rotated. In order to measure participants’ experience, participants will also report whether they have ever written a review on a rating site (e.g., Yelp, TripAdvisor, Amazon) before (1 = never, 2 = once, 3 = 2-3 times, 4 = 4-5 times, 5 = more than 5 times).  Finally, participants will report their age and gender.

Since we have a binary dependent variable, we will use x2 (chi-square) analysis in order to compare percent (%) of people who would share a photo together with the email in each condition. We will also use ANOVA to determine differences in manipulation checks between the two conditions.

attributes.title: Within- and between-subject consistency of perceptual segmentation in periodic noise

q1.value: Within- and between-subject consistency of perceptual segmentation in periodic noise

q2.value: Hanna Ringer, Erich Schröger, Sabine Grimm

q3.value: Previous research has suggested that the human auditory system relies on subtle temporally local and idiosyncratic features to perceptually segment auditory information that does not contain any outstanding acoustic landmarks, such as periodic white noise. The aim of the proposed study is to show that individuals differ in how they perceptually segment periodic noise while each listener is consistent with oneself. This finding would support the claim that memory representations are established for features which are idiosyncratic in nature.

q4.value:
If listeners rely on idiosyncratic features for perceptual segmentation, this should result in a high temporal consistency across presentations of the same periodic noise sequence within one individual, assuming that one person would always perceive the same time point within the cycle (at which the chosen feature occurs) as cycle onset. Conversely, the subjective repetition onset might be shifted in time between listeners because each of them relies on a different subtle feature as a cue for segmentation of the sequence, leading to a low temporal consistency between subjects. 
Consequently, periodicity-related event-related potentials (ERPs) to fully periodic noise sequences (in which essentially any time point could be perceived as cycle onset; see Question 16 for a more detailed description of the stimulus conditions) are expected to be levelled out on the group level while cyclic ERPs time-locked to the perceived cycle onset (a negativity peaking between 150 and 350 ms after cycle onset, sometimes preceded by an early positive component) should be observable on the single-subject level. Similarly, periodicity-related ERPs are assumed to be time-shifted between fully periodic sequences formed of different specific noise patterns also within one individual. 
In contrast, if the subtle structure of a noise sequence is semi-periodic and only allows time points within a narrower time window to be perceived as cycle onset, periodicity-related ERPs time-locked to cycle onset should also be present at the group level as the possible time-shift between subjects is considerably reduced, thus the temporal between-subject consistency is enhanced. 
High temporal consistency of perceptual segmentation within one subject as well as low temporal consistency between subjects should also be reflected in the phase coherence of brain responses evoked by the periodicity in the stimuli. Concretely, we hypothesize that inter-trial phase coherence (ITPC) of oscillatory activity at the frequency of the stimulation will be comparably high within each subject for both fully periodic and semi-periodic sequences. In contrast, the two types of periodicity are expected to differ with regard to phase coherence between listeners: inter-subject phase coherence (ISPC) is assumed to be considerably weaker in response to fully periodic compared to semi-periodic sequences.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Conditions will be arranged in a within-subject design with one factor (periodicity of the noise sequence) with three levels (fully periodic, semi-periodic and random noise sequences). Within each of the conditions, four different sequences (i.e. formed of different specific noise patterns) will be used as stimuli.

The different types of periodicity will be introduced to the participants at the beginning of the EEG experiment as noise sequences that either contain a strong rhythm (fully periodic), a weaker rhythm (semi-periodic) or no rhythm (random). They will be presented with example stimuli for each type of sequence and informed that those will occur at equal probability. During the experiment, they will be asked to indicate via button press after each sequence whether they have heard a rhythm or not. 

EEG will be recorded at 32 scalp locations according to the 10-20 system as well as at left and right mastoid positions. Additionally, EOG will be recorded from four electrodes placed at the outer canthi of each eye and below and above the right eye. Data will be referenced to an electrode placed on the tip of the noise and digitized at a sampling rate of 512 Hz

q9.value: Sequences of the three periodicity conditions will be presented in blocks with every block containing an equal number of sequences from each of the conditions (and also an equal number of each of the four specific noise patterns per condition). Within each block, fully periodic, semi-periodic and random noise sequences will be randomized following the restriction that the same periodicity condition must not occur in more than two trials in a row.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value:
As of the date of submission of this preregistration, data collection has already been started (but not yet completed) due to time constraints arising from the fact that this project is realized in the context of a master thesis. We will, however, not start analyzing the data before the final sample size (specified in Question 13) is reached.

Before starting data collection of the final sample, we have already tested three pilot participants whose data will not be included in the final, preregistered analysis. Pilot participants were tested in order to make sure that the procedure that was planned based on theoretical assumptions is actually feasible (e.g. with regard to the duration of an experimental session for the participants and the signal-to-noise ratio in the data).

question.value: Subjects will be recruited from a pool of undergraduate psychology students at the University of Leipzig who will receive course credits or monetary compensation (8€ per hour) for their participation. To participate in the study, they have to be between 18 and 40 years old and have normal hearing and must not report any history of neurological or psychiatric disorder.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 24 participants whose data will be included in the final analysis. If some of them have to be excluded from the analysis (see Question 22 for exclusion criteria) due to bad EEG data quality, i.e. not enough artefact-free epochs after artefact rejection (following the procedures described in Question 20), a correspondingly higher number of subjects will be tested.

q14.value: With a sample size of 24 participants we will be able to detect an effect size of 0.7 in a two-tailed t-test at the standard .05 alpha error probability with a power of .90. The expected effect size was estimated from simulations based on the amplitudes of periodicity-related cyclic ERPs reported previously (Andrillon et al., 2015; Berti et al., 2000) assuming a certain noise level based on a dataset acquired earlier with the same EEG system and settings.

q15.value: Data collection will be stopped when the planned sample size (specified in Question 13) is reached.

question.value: We will manipulate the periodicity of the white noise sequences that will serve as auditory stimuli. These sequences can be either fully periodic, i.e. consisting of seamlessly concatenated repetitions of a 500 ms noise segment, semi-periodic, i.e. consisting of a 200 ms noise segment (i.e. the first 200 ms of the 500 ms segment used in the fully periodic sequences) being repeated every 500 ms and random noise portions inserted between the repetitions, or random, i.e. not containing any temporal regularity. Fully periodic and semi-periodic sequences will consist of ten full cycles and random sequences will be matched in duration. Four different sequences will be created per condition with each of them being formed of a specific (randomly generated) pattern. In order to temporally separate sequence onset and periodicity onset, a random noise portion varying in length between 50 and 450 ms will be inserted at the beginning of each exemplar of a sequence (30 per condition and pattern) and the interval between trials will be jittered between 1150 and 1850 ms duration (in steps of 100 ms) to avoid a temporal regularity across trials.

Electrophysiological responses to the auditory stimuli belonging to different periodicity conditions will be measured and analyzed in terms of two EEG markers, that is periodicity-related ERPs to cycle onset (or corresponding time points in random noise sequences) and phase coherence of evoked oscillatory activity in the frequency of the stimulation (i.e. 2 Hz) within and between subjects.

Cluster-based permutation tests will be used to identify significant clusters of periodicity-related ERP activity comparing ERPs to fully periodic and semi-periodic sequences against ERPs to random sequences, respectively. Additionally, difference potentials between either type of regularity and random noise will be compared to identify specific activity clusters that differ between fully periodic and semi-periodic sequences.  
Pairwise t-tests will be performed to statistically evaluate differences in ITPC and ISPC at 2 Hz, i.e. the frequency of the periodicity in the stimulation, between fully periodic, semi-periodic and random condition.

q20.value:
Firstly, the EEG data will be offline low- and high-pass filtered with Kaiser-windowed sinc FIR filters at 35 Hz (transition bandwidth: 5 Hz, maximum passband deviation: 0.001) and 0.2 Hz (transition bandwidth: 0.4 Hz, maximum passband deviation: 0.001), respectively. If the signal variance of a channel exceeds a z-score of 3.0, this channel will be excluded and spherically spline interpolated after removing artefacts. The filtered continuous data will be cut into epochs starting 100 ms before and ending 6000 ms after sequence onset (i.e. approximately 500 ms after sequence offset). Following this, an independent component analysis (ICA) will be used to clean the data from physiological and technical artefacts. To improve the signal-to-noise ratio for decomposition, ICA will be computed on a copy of the data that has been filtered with a 1 Hz high-pass (Kaiser-windowed sinc FIR filter, transition bandwidth: 0.5 Hz, maximum passband deviation: 0.001) and a 35 Hz low-pass filter (Kaiser-windowed sinc FIR filter, transition bandwidth 5 Hz, maximum passband deviation: 0.001) and epoched as described above. Epochs whose maximal peak-to-peak difference exceeds 750 µV will be excluded from the ICA decomposition and the data will be down-sampled to 128 Hz before extracting independent components to shorten computation time. ICA weights will then be transferred to the EEG data pre-processed with the final parameters and independent components will be classified using the EEGLAB ICLabel plug-in (Pion-Tonachini, Kreutz-Delgado, & Makeig, 2019). Artefactual components such as those classified as eye blinks, muscle activity or channel noise will be removed. 
For the analysis of ERPs, shorter epochs will be extracted ranging from -100 ms to 500 ms relative to the onset of a repeated segment (or corresponding time points in random noise sequences). The first and the last full cycle within each epoch will be excluded to minimize the influence of sequence onset and offset effects, resulting in 240 epochs per condition for each subject and each of the four different noise patterns. Epochs still exceeding a 150 µV peak-to-peak difference will be discarded from further analysis and, finally, the remaining epochs will be averaged separately for each of the four noise patterns as well as across them and re-referenced to the algebraic mean of the two mastoid electrode sites (M1, M2). 
For analysis in the frequency domain, sequence-epochs will be cut ranging from periodicity onset to periodicity offset, thus covering the ten full periodic cycles (or a corresponding time window for random sequences). In two parallel analyses, ITPC within each subject and ISPC across subjects will be estimated for each channel within each periodicity condition and each noise pattern. For both analyses, a convolution with Morlet wavelets will be applied, either subject-wise across trials belonging to the same condition and noise pattern (ITPC) or trial-wise across subjects (ISPC). Parameters of the Morlet wavelet will be adjusted linearly from five to ten wavelet cycles over a range from 0.4 to 10 Hz. Noise pattern-specific ITPC and ISPC maps within each periodicity condition will subsequently be averaged to improve signal-to-noise ratio. For statistical evaluation between conditions, both ITPC and ISPC will be averaged across a 0.4 Hz wide frequency window centered around the frequency of the periodicity in the stimulation, i.e. 2 Hz, in a time window ranging from the onset of the first repetition to the end of the sequence, i.e. the second to the tenth cycle.
Additionally, a fast Fourier transform (FFT) will be performed on the sequence-wise epochs within each subject and averaged across the four noise patterns within each periodicity condition to extract power in a frequency bin centered around 2 Hz (+/- 0.2 Hz) for each periodicity condition and each noise pattern. Power will then be compared between conditions using pairwise t-tests to explore whether there are any power differences which might at least partly account for differences in phase coherence.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criterion to determine if results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis was correct. False discovery rate (FDR) correction (Benjamini & Hochberg, 1995) will be applied to account for multiple comparisons where appropriate.

q22.value: Participants will be excluded from the analysis if only less than 120 artefact-free epochs (i.e. less than 50% of all epochs) remain in any condition after artefact rejection (following the procedures described in Question 20).

q23.value: If data of a participant are incomplete, this participant will be excluded from the analysis if the criterion specified in Question 22 applies.

q25.value:
The reliable estimation of the phase of oscillatory activity is crucially dependent on the signal-to-noise ratio in the data. Thus, if the signal-to-noise ratio in our data turns out to be poor, analysis of phase coherence might not provide conclusive results with regard to the temporal consistency of cyclic periodicity-related brain responses within and between subjects. Therefore, we propose an alternative approach to analyze time-shifts of periodicity-related ERPs within a cycle occurring on the within- and between-subject level. This procedure will be followed if the ITPC coefficients (at 2 Hz; averaged across all four noise patterns) in the semi-periodic condition fail to reach statistical significance from those in the random condition (as assessed with a paired t-test on the group-level). 
Single-subject average ERPs for each noise pattern in fully and semi-periodic conditions will be denoised applying a wavelet denoising method (Quian Quiroga & Garcia, 2003). ERP peak latencies of minima within a cycle will then be extracted relative to cycle onset from the denoised ERPs. Subsequently, variance of the latencies across subjects will be compared between the two different types of periodicity (separately for each pattern as well as averaged across them), assuming that larger variance in latencies reflects a larger phase-shift of periodicity-related ERPs. It is expected that variance between subjects will be considerably higher in the fully periodic compared to semi-periodic condition. Having extracted the individual ERP latency for each subject in each condition, this will allow us to calculate group-level average ERPs that are corrected for potential phase-shifts between subjects and compare (peak) amplitudes between fully periodic and semi-periodic condition (by means of a cluster-based permutation test).  

After the EEG experiment and a short break, participants will complete another short behavioral experiment. They will listen to the same fully periodic and semi-periodic noise sequences again and will be asked to tap with their finger in synchrony with the perceived rhythm of the auditory stimulus. In a separate block at the end of the tapping experiment, participants will be presented with control sequences that contain temporally regular physical changes (increasing a 1 ms segment of random noise in intensity by approximately 12dB SPL every 500 ms) in the signal, usually perceived as a clicking sound in the noise, to get an estimate of the maximal tapping synchrony achieved when there is an obvious acoustic cue in the stimulus. 
For each condition (fully periodic, semi-periodic and physical changes) and each specific noise pattern in fully periodic and semi-periodic conditions, the mean tapping rate across presentations of the same sequence as well as its standard deviation will be extracted. Additionally, synchrony of participants’ tapping relative to the periodicity of the auditory stimulation will be analyzed for each condition and each of the four different specific noise patterns. To this end, mean and standard deviation of the time lags between the time of the tap and the time of the actual onset of a pattern repetition or physical change will be calculated for each subject, indicating how precisely the taps are synchronized with the auditory rhythm and how temporally consistent the rhythm of the tapping is. Finally, we will explore potential associations between the phase coherence of the cyclic ERPs and consistency of participants’ tapping.

registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q9: Sequences of the three periodicity conditions will be presented in blocks with every block containing an equal number of sequences from each of the conditions (and also an equal number of each of the four specific noise patterns per condition). Within each block, fully periodic, semi-periodic and random noise sequences will be randomized following the restriction that the same periodicity condition must not occur in more than two trials in a row.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11:
As of the date of submission of this preregistration, data collection has already been started (but not yet completed) due to time constraints arising from the fact that this project is realized in the context of a master thesis. We will, however, not start analyzing the data before the final sample size (specified in Question 13) is reached.

Before starting data collection of the final sample, we have already tested three pilot participants whose data will not be included in the final, preregistered analysis. Pilot participants were tested in order to make sure that the procedure that was planned based on theoretical assumptions is actually feasible (e.g. with regard to the duration of an experimental session for the participants and the signal-to-noise ratio in the data).
registration_responses.q13: Our target sample size is 24 participants whose data will be included in the final analysis. If some of them have to be excluded from the analysis (see Question 22 for exclusion criteria) due to bad EEG data quality, i.e. not enough artefact-free epochs after artefact rejection (following the procedures described in Question 20), a correspondingly higher number of subjects will be tested.
registration_responses.q14: With a sample size of 24 participants we will be able to detect an effect size of 0.7 in a two-tailed t-test at the standard .05 alpha error probability with a power of .90. The expected effect size was estimated from simulations based on the amplitudes of periodicity-related cyclic ERPs reported previously (Andrillon et al., 2015; Berti et al., 2000) assuming a certain noise level based on a dataset acquired earlier with the same EEG system and settings.
registration_responses.q15: Data collection will be stopped when the planned sample size (specified in Question 13) is reached.
registration_responses.q20:
Firstly, the EEG data will be offline low- and high-pass filtered with Kaiser-windowed sinc FIR filters at 35 Hz (transition bandwidth: 5 Hz, maximum passband deviation: 0.001) and 0.2 Hz (transition bandwidth: 0.4 Hz, maximum passband deviation: 0.001), respectively. If the signal variance of a channel exceeds a z-score of 3.0, this channel will be excluded and spherically spline interpolated after removing artefacts. The filtered continuous data will be cut into epochs starting 100 ms before and ending 6000 ms after sequence onset (i.e. approximately 500 ms after sequence offset). Following this, an independent component analysis (ICA) will be used to clean the data from physiological and technical artefacts. To improve the signal-to-noise ratio for decomposition, ICA will be computed on a copy of the data that has been filtered with a 1 Hz high-pass (Kaiser-windowed sinc FIR filter, transition bandwidth: 0.5 Hz, maximum passband deviation: 0.001) and a 35 Hz low-pass filter (Kaiser-windowed sinc FIR filter, transition bandwidth 5 Hz, maximum passband deviation: 0.001) and epoched as described above. Epochs whose maximal peak-to-peak difference exceeds 750 µV will be excluded from the ICA decomposition and the data will be down-sampled to 128 Hz before extracting independent components to shorten computation time. ICA weights will then be transferred to the EEG data pre-processed with the final parameters and independent components will be classified using the EEGLAB ICLabel plug-in (Pion-Tonachini, Kreutz-Delgado, & Makeig, 2019). Artefactual components such as those classified as eye blinks, muscle activity or channel noise will be removed. 
For the analysis of ERPs, shorter epochs will be extracted ranging from -100 ms to 500 ms relative to the onset of a repeated segment (or corresponding time points in random noise sequences). The first and the last full cycle within each epoch will be excluded to minimize the influence of sequence onset and offset effects, resulting in 240 epochs per condition for each subject and each of the four different noise patterns. Epochs still exceeding a 150 µV peak-to-peak difference will be discarded from further analysis and, finally, the remaining epochs will be averaged separately for each of the four noise patterns as well as across them and re-referenced to the algebraic mean of the two mastoid electrode sites (M1, M2). 
For analysis in the frequency domain, sequence-epochs will be cut ranging from periodicity onset to periodicity offset, thus covering the ten full periodic cycles (or a corresponding time window for random sequences). In two parallel analyses, ITPC within each subject and ISPC across subjects will be estimated for each channel within each periodicity condition and each noise pattern. For both analyses, a convolution with Morlet wavelets will be applied, either subject-wise across trials belonging to the same condition and noise pattern (ITPC) or trial-wise across subjects (ISPC). Parameters of the Morlet wavelet will be adjusted linearly from five to ten wavelet cycles over a range from 0.4 to 10 Hz. Noise pattern-specific ITPC and ISPC maps within each periodicity condition will subsequently be averaged to improve signal-to-noise ratio. For statistical evaluation between conditions, both ITPC and ISPC will be averaged across a 0.4 Hz wide frequency window centered around the frequency of the periodicity in the stimulation, i.e. 2 Hz, in a time window ranging from the onset of the first repetition to the end of the sequence, i.e. the second to the tenth cycle.
Additionally, a fast Fourier transform (FFT) will be performed on the sequence-wise epochs within each subject and averaged across the four noise patterns within each periodicity condition to extract power in a frequency bin centered around 2 Hz (+/- 0.2 Hz) for each periodicity condition and each noise pattern. Power will then be compared between conditions using pairwise t-tests to explore whether there are any power differences which might at least partly account for differences in phase coherence.
registration_responses.q21: We will use the standard p<.05 criterion to determine if results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis was correct. False discovery rate (FDR) correction (Benjamini & Hochberg, 1995) will be applied to account for multiple comparisons where appropriate.
registration_responses.q22: Participants will be excluded from the analysis if only less than 120 artefact-free epochs (i.e. less than 50% of all epochs) remain in any condition after artefact rejection (following the procedures described in Question 20).
registration_responses.q23: If data of a participant are incomplete, this participant will be excluded from the analysis if the criterion specified in Question 22 applies.
registration_responses.q25:
The reliable estimation of the phase of oscillatory activity is crucially dependent on the signal-to-noise ratio in the data. Thus, if the signal-to-noise ratio in our data turns out to be poor, analysis of phase coherence might not provide conclusive results with regard to the temporal consistency of cyclic periodicity-related brain responses within and between subjects. Therefore, we propose an alternative approach to analyze time-shifts of periodicity-related ERPs within a cycle occurring on the within- and between-subject level. This procedure will be followed if the ITPC coefficients (at 2 Hz; averaged across all four noise patterns) in the semi-periodic condition fail to reach statistical significance from those in the random condition (as assessed with a paired t-test on the group-level). 
Single-subject average ERPs for each noise pattern in fully and semi-periodic conditions will be denoised applying a wavelet denoising method (Quian Quiroga & Garcia, 2003). ERP peak latencies of minima within a cycle will then be extracted relative to cycle onset from the denoised ERPs. Subsequently, variance of the latencies across subjects will be compared between the two different types of periodicity (separately for each pattern as well as averaged across them), assuming that larger variance in latencies reflects a larger phase-shift of periodicity-related ERPs. It is expected that variance between subjects will be considerably higher in the fully periodic compared to semi-periodic condition. Having extracted the individual ERP latency for each subject in each condition, this will allow us to calculate group-level average ERPs that are corrected for potential phase-shifts between subjects and compare (peak) amplitudes between fully periodic and semi-periodic condition (by means of a cluster-based permutation test).  

After the EEG experiment and a short break, participants will complete another short behavioral experiment. They will listen to the same fully periodic and semi-periodic noise sequences again and will be asked to tap with their finger in synchrony with the perceived rhythm of the auditory stimulus. In a separate block at the end of the tapping experiment, participants will be presented with control sequences that contain temporally regular physical changes (increasing a 1 ms segment of random noise in intensity by approximately 12dB SPL every 500 ms) in the signal, usually perceived as a clicking sound in the noise, to get an estimate of the maximal tapping synchrony achieved when there is an obvious acoustic cue in the stimulus. 
For each condition (fully periodic, semi-periodic and physical changes) and each specific noise pattern in fully periodic and semi-periodic conditions, the mean tapping rate across presentations of the same sequence as well as its standard deviation will be extracted. Additionally, synchrony of participants’ tapping relative to the periodicity of the auditory stimulation will be analyzed for each condition and each of the four different specific noise patterns. To this end, mean and standard deviation of the time lags between the time of the tap and the time of the actual onset of a pattern repetition or physical change will be calculated for each subject, indicating how precisely the taps are synchronized with the auditory rhythm and how temporally consistent the rhythm of the tapping is. Finally, we will explore potential associations between the phase coherence of the cyclic ERPs and consistency of participants’ tapping.
registration_responses.q8.question:
Conditions will be arranged in a within-subject design with one factor (periodicity of the noise sequence) with three levels (fully periodic, semi-periodic and random noise sequences). Within each of the conditions, four different sequences (i.e. formed of different specific noise patterns) will be used as stimuli.

The different types of periodicity will be introduced to the participants at the beginning of the EEG experiment as noise sequences that either contain a strong rhythm (fully periodic), a weaker rhythm (semi-periodic) or no rhythm (random). They will be presented with example stimuli for each type of sequence and informed that those will occur at equal probability. During the experiment, they will be asked to indicate via button press after each sequence whether they have heard a rhythm or not. 

EEG will be recorded at 32 scalp locations according to the 10-20 system as well as at left and right mastoid positions. Additionally, EOG will be recorded from four electrodes placed at the outer canthi of each eye and below and above the right eye. Data will be referenced to an electrode placed on the tip of the noise and digitized at a sampling rate of 512 Hz
registration_responses.q12.question: Subjects will be recruited from a pool of undergraduate psychology students at the University of Leipzig who will receive course credits or monetary compensation (8€ per hour) for their participation. To participate in the study, they have to be between 18 and 40 years old and have normal hearing and must not report any history of neurological or psychiatric disorder.
registration_responses.q16.question: We will manipulate the periodicity of the white noise sequences that will serve as auditory stimuli. These sequences can be either fully periodic, i.e. consisting of seamlessly concatenated repetitions of a 500 ms noise segment, semi-periodic, i.e. consisting of a 200 ms noise segment (i.e. the first 200 ms of the 500 ms segment used in the fully periodic sequences) being repeated every 500 ms and random noise portions inserted between the repetitions, or random, i.e. not containing any temporal regularity. Fully periodic and semi-periodic sequences will consist of ten full cycles and random sequences will be matched in duration. Four different sequences will be created per condition with each of them being formed of a specific (randomly generated) pattern. In order to temporally separate sequence onset and periodicity onset, a random noise portion varying in length between 50 and 450 ms will be inserted at the beginning of each exemplar of a sequence (30 per condition and pattern) and the interval between trials will be jittered between 1150 and 1850 ms duration (in steps of 100 ms) to avoid a temporal regularity across trials.
registration_responses.q17.question: Electrophysiological responses to the auditory stimuli belonging to different periodicity conditions will be measured and analyzed in terms of two EEG markers, that is periodicity-related ERPs to cycle onset (or corresponding time points in random noise sequences) and phase coherence of evoked oscillatory activity in the frequency of the stimulation (i.e. 2 Hz) within and between subjects.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Cluster-based permutation tests will be used to identify significant clusters of periodicity-related ERP activity comparing ERPs to fully periodic and semi-periodic sequences against ERPs to random sequences, respectively. Additionally, difference potentials between either type of regularity and random noise will be compared to identify specific activity clusters that differ between fully periodic and semi-periodic sequences.  
Pairwise t-tests will be performed to statistically evaluate differences in ITPC and ISPC at 2 Hz, i.e. the frequency of the periodicity in the stimulation, between fully periodic, semi-periodic and random condition.
